The Rose family.

 Petals: 5

 Sepals: 5

 Stamens: many

 Styles: many

 Info: sepals alternate with petals. Oval shaped serrated leaves. The many stamens is particularly characteristic of this family.

 Do not expect cultivated varieties to adhere to these patterns.

 Could be confused with members of the Ranunculaceae (Buttercup) family, however Buttercup leaves never have stipules.

The Pea family, the legumes.

 5 united petals.

 Usually 10 stamens.

 Ovary matures into a pea pod.

 Legumes can be identified by the petals arranged to form the: banner, wings, and keel. The banner is a single large petal with two lobes, usually at the top. Beneath this are two smaller 'wing' petals. The keel is made of the two smallest petals, united at the bottom.

The Pink family.

 2 to 5 styles.

 5 OR 10 stamens, arranged in 1 or 2 whorls

 5 petals, the ends are often split.

 5 sepals.

 Superior ovary.

 Info: Members usually have opposite leaves.

The Heath/Blueberry family.

 4 or 5 united sepals.

 4 or 5 united petals. Often urn or bell shaped.

 Info: Leaves are usually evergreen. The urn shaped petals are a great diagnostic helper. Most members are shrubs. Thrive on poorly drained acidic soils.

The Buckwheat/Knotweed family.
Plants typically have many small flowers.

 No petals.
 5-6 coloured sepals. 3 to 9 stamens.
 3 styles.

 Info: swollen joints/nodes on the stems (Polygonum means many-knees).

 Flowers in fascicles, which are then arranged on inflorescences.

The Carrot/Parsley family.

 Flowers arranged in compound umbels.
 5 petals.
 5 stamens.

The Lily family.

 3 petals and 3 sepals, often the same size and colour.
 6 stamens.
 Pistil with a 3-parted stigma.
 Leaves with parallel veins.
